Leafy appendage subtending a flower or an inflorescence in its axil
Leafy appendage subtending an individual flower of an inflorescence; a secondary bract
An outward extension of the base of a trunk of a tree
The outer whorl of the flower (sepals)
A combination of branches and leaves, applied to the covering of a tree or the covering of a fores
(of fruit) Dry fruit resulting from several united carpels, splitting variously at maturity
A single unit of the pistil which consists of the ovary, style and stigma
Production of flowers on the trunk and branches
Provided with small hairs on the margins
(of leaves) Divided into 2 or more parts (leaflets)
racemoxe inflorescence with a flat-topped flower-cluster
Branches and leaves forming the top of the tree
(of leaf apices) terminating in an abruptly pointed tip
A branching inflorescence, the main axis terminating with a flower
Not evergreen; leaves falling off seasonally
(of leaves) An opposite pairs at a node lying at right angles to the next
(of fruits) Splitting open at maturity to release seeds
(of leaves) Arising from a common point at the end of the petiole
With male and female flowers borne on separate plants; opp. monoecious
A fleshy fruit containing one or more seeds, each of which is surrounded by a stony layer
Shaped like an ellipse, narrow at both ends and widest in the middle
(of apices) Shallowly notched in the middle
(of species) Native to one region and not found native elsewhere
(of leaf margin) Not divided or lobed
(of flowers) When the position of the sepals, petals and stamens is above the ovary making the ovary inferior (below) to other floral parts; opp. hypogynous
(epiphytic) growing on top other plants (but no parasite)
(of sap of a tree) To flow out or bleed slowly
A taxonomic unit of classification of plants comprising related genera
(of tree bark) Deep or shallow cracks on the surface of bark
A dry fruit derived from a single carpel and which splits along one side
The ripened ovary of a seed plant with all its contents
Monstrous growth of part of the plant as a result of a parasitic attack by an insect
(sing.) genera (pl.) A taxonomic unit of classification of plants containing related species
Special secreting cells, may be stalked or sessile
The characteristic mode of growth of a plant; the form and shape of a plant
An individual produced from a cross between two different species
A cup-like structure enclosing the ovary, derived from the fusion of the receptacle and the outer floral parts
(of flowers) When the position of the sepals, petals and stamens is below the ovary making the ovary superior (above) to other floral parts; opp. epigynous
A pinnately compound leaf with an unpaired terminal leaflet
(of fruits) Not opening at maturity to release seeds
Arrangement of flowers on the flowering stalk
Portion of the branch between two nodes
A crest formed at the node of a stem by opposing leaf stipules
A linear scar on branches on the joining the petioles of opposing leaves that is formed by abscising stipule(s)
(of leaves) A vein running parallel to the leaf margin
(= scalariform venation) tertiary veins arising perpendicular to secondary veins, resulting in a ladder-like appearance
(of leaf) lance-shaped, broadest in the middle and tapering at both ends
On or at the side or margin
Single leafy part, or the smallest component of a compound leaf
Corky spots on the bark of trees that allow gas exchange
A woody climber, supported by other vegetation
(of leaves in flowering plants) a distal projection from the base of the petiole, e.g. in grasses
Long and narrow, with parallel sides
Growing along the sea or lake shore
(of leaves) The outer edge of the leaf blade
The middle and major vein of a leaf
Male and female flowers borne on the same plant
A genus of family containing a single species
(of leaf apex) Leaf apex narrowing to a sharp point in the middle or with a soft or hard spine in the middle
(of flowers) Open at night and close during the day
(of branch) Location at which leaves are attached
(of fruit) A dry, usually one-seeded, indehiscent fruit with a woody fruit wall
(of leaf) Broadest towards the apex, tapering towards the base
(of leaf-base) Not straight or symmetrical, unequally sided
Longer than broad with parallel margins
(of leaf) Having the broadest part above the middle, opposite of ovate
(of leaves) Borne in pairs at each node on opposite sides of the stem
Ovule bearing part of the gynoecium; superior – borne above the attachment of stamens and perianth; inferior – borne below the attachment of stamens and perianth
(of leaf) Egg-shaped in outline, with the broadest part below the middle, opp. obovate
(of leaves and venation) leaflets or leaf segments or veins arising from a single point on an axis
Butterfly-like (said of flowers of some of the pea-family)
A plant which lives and is dependent for its nutrition on another plant.
A pinnately compound leaf with an equal number of leaflets on either side of the axis, without the terminal leaflet
leaf blade with the petiole attached inside the leaf margin rather at the edge
Collective term for the sepals and corolla, or for the petals
The mark left on the stem after abscission of the leaf
Leaf-like parts of a flower surrounding the gynoeciom
The stalk of a leaf attaching it to the stem
A modified stem, in form and function like a leaf
(of compound leaves, also for venation) With leaflets (or veins) on either side of the leaf stalk (or midrib)
Fast growing species which colonise newly disturbed sites such as forest clearings
A dry fruit with usually more than a single seed; term used for the fruit of a legume
A forest that has not previously been disturbed
Species, normally slow growing, which dominate an undisturbed forest
An inflorescence of stalked flowers with the youngest at the top
The axis of a compound leaf or inflorescense
A sticky substance secreted by special cells in conifers
rounded or obtuse apex with central shallow notch
A dry indehiscent fruit with the fruit wall extended to form a flattened wing
A pinnate venation where the lateral veins are joined by tranverse intralateral veins
Fruit which splits at maturity into 1-seeded portions
A forest which has been disturbed through logging or clearing
Plant living on another plant and deriving its nutrition from it, but not entirely dependent on it
(of leaves) With the base of leaf or petiole enveloping or enclosing the stem
A racemose inflorescence, with the flowers sessile along a common unbranched axis
The male sex organ of a plant consisting of the anther, connective and filament
Not fertile, not able to reproduce sexually
The apical part of the style which receives the pollen
Paired, often leaf-like appendages, at the base of leaf (may be variously modified as tendrils, spines etc.)
Prefix meaning slightly less or not quite or somewhat
Open, degraded land covered with grasses, ferns or reeds (occurring in the drier parts of Fiji), often burned.
Part or all of a stem, leaf or petiole modified to form a thin appendage with an ability to coil around objects, forming a climbing part of the plant
Undeveloped, condensed shoot at the apex of a stem
A branching pattern that is typical of the genus Terminalia with smaller branches curving upward from bigger branches
Mixed inflorescene with the main axis a raceme and secondary axes in the form of cymes
An inflorescence with pedicels arising from a common point, usually umbrella-shaped
A layer of small trees or shrubs in a tropical forest
(of flowers) Of one sex, either with stamens or carpels
(of flowers) parts of the corolla or calyx meet exactly without overlapping
A taxonomic unit within a species
The visible conducting or strengthening tissue of a leaf
hairy With smooth and soft hairs, like velvet
The arrangement of veins of a leaf
